idAbs.para: Calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of cells in a raster.

summary.para: Calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of cells in a raster.

pythonReference.para: The input for which to calculate the inverse hyperbolic tangent values.
In order to use a number as an input for this parameter, the cell size and extent must first be set in the environment.

dialogReference.para: The input for which to calculate the inverse hyperbolic tangent values.
In order to use a number as an input for this parameter, the cell size and extent must first be set in the environment.

pythonReference.para: The values are the inverse hyperbolic tangent of the input values.

dialogReference.para: The values are the inverse hyperbolic tangent of the input values.

bullet_item.para: In mathematics, all Trigonometric functions have a defined range of valid input values, called the domain. The output values from each function also has a defined range. For this tool:
Note that any input value that is outside this domain will receive NoData on the output raster.
Note that here -∞ and ∞ represent the smallest negative and largest positive value supported by the particular raster format, respectively.
The input and output values in ATanH are interpreted as unitless.
Output values are always floating point, regardless of the input data type.

scriptExample.title: ATanH example 1 (Python window)
scriptExample.para: This example calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of the values in the input GRID raster.
scriptExample.code: import arcpy from arcpy import env from arcpy.sa import * env.workspace = "C:/sapyexamples/data" outATanH = ATanH("degs") outATanH.save("C:/sapyexamples/output/outatanh")

scriptExample.title: ATanH example 2 (stand-alone script)
scriptExample.para: This example calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of the values in the input GRID raster.
scriptExample.code:
# Name: ATanH_Ex_02.py # Description: Calculates the inverse hyperbolic tangent of cells # in a raster # Requirements: Spatial Analyst Extension # Author: ESRI
# Import system modules import arcpy from arcpy import env from arcpy.sa import *
# Set environment settings env.workspace = "C:/sapyexamples/data"
# Set local variables inRaster = "degs"
# Check out the ArcGIS Spatial Analyst extension license arcpy.CheckOutExtension("Spatial")
# Execute TanH outATanH = ATanH(inRaster)
# Save the output outATanH.save("C:/sapyexamples/output/outatanh.img")
